t: Psalm 68
For the director of music. Of David. A psalm. A song.
May*pn God arise, may his enemies be scattered; may*ld his foes flee before him.
May*ln you blow them away like smoke— as*ld wax melts before the fire, may*ld the wicked perish before God.
But*ln may the righteous be glad and*ld rejoice before God; may*ld they be happy and joyful.
Sing*pn to God, sing in praise of his name, extol*ld him who rides on the clouds; rejoice*ld before him—his name is the Lord.*s
A*ln father to the fatherless, a defender of widows, is*ld God in his holy dwelling.
God*ln sets the lonely in families, he*ld leads out the prisoners with singing; but*ld the rebellious live in a sun-scorched land.
When*pn you, God, went out before your people, when*ld you marched through the wilderness,
the*ln earth shook, the heavens poured down rain, before*ld God, the One of Sinai, before*ld God, the God of Israel.
You*ln gave abundant showers, O God; you*ld refreshed your weary inheritance.
Your*ln people settled in it, and*ld from your bounty, God, you provided for the poor.
The*pn Lord announces the word, and*ld the women who proclaim it are a mighty throng:
“Kings*ln and armies flee in haste; the*ld women at home divide the plunder.
Even*ln while you sleep among the sheep pens, the*ld wings of my dove are sheathed with silver, its*ld feathers with shining gold.”
When*ln the Almighty scattered the kings in the land, it*ld was like snow fallen on Mount Zalmon.
Mount*pn Bashan, majestic mountain, Mount*ld Bashan, rugged mountain,
why*ln gaze in envy, you rugged mountain, at*ld the mountain where God chooses to reign, where*ld the Lord*s himself will dwell forever?
The*ln chariots of God are tens of thousands and*ld thousands of thousands; the*ld Lord has come from Sinai into his sanctuary.
When*ln you ascended on high, you*ld took many captives; you*ld received gifts from people, even*ln from the rebellious— that*ld you, Lord*s God, might dwell there.
Praise*pn be to the Lord, to God our Savior, who*ld daily bears our burdens.
Our*ln God is a God who saves; from*ld the Sovereign Lord*s comes escape from death.
Surely*ln God will crush the heads of his enemies, the*ld hairy crowns of those who go on in their sins.
The*ln Lord says, “I will bring them from Bashan; I*ld will bring them from the depths of the sea,
that*ln your feet may wade in the blood of your foes, while*ld the tongues of your dogs have their share.”
Your*pn procession, God, has come into view, the*ld procession of my God and King into the sanctuary.
In*ln front are the singers, after them the musicians; with*ld them are the young women playing the timbrels.
Praise*ln God in the great congregation; praise*ld the Lord*s in the assembly of Israel.
There*ln is the little tribe of Benjamin, leading them, there*ld the great throng of Judah’s princes, and*ld there the princes of Zebulun and of Naphtali.
Summon*pn your power, God; show*ld us your strength, our God, as you have done before.
Because*ln of your temple at Jerusalem kings*ld will bring you gifts.
Rebuke*ln the beast among the reeds, the*ld herd of bulls among the calves of the nations. Humbled,*ln may the beast bring bars of silver. Scatter*ld the nations who delight in war.
Envoys*ln will come from Egypt; Cush*ld will submit herself to God.
Sing*pn to God, you kingdoms of the earth, sing*ld praise to the Lord,
to*ln him who rides across the highest heavens, the ancient heavens, who*ld thunders with mighty voice.
Proclaim*ln the power of God, whose*ld majesty is over Israel, whose*ld power is in the heavens.
You,*ln God, are awesome in your sanctuary; the*ld God of Israel gives power and strength to his people. Praise*pn be to God!
